Award.AwardTitle: Tuning Dynamo Models to Paleomagnetic Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout Earth's history records of the geomagnetic field have been preserved in archeological artifacts, or in globally distributed sedimentary and igneous rocks. Compilations of archeomagnetic and paleomagnetic data with associated age constraints are now routinely used to make continuous time-varying models of the geomagnetic field that can extend from the present to 10 thousand years ago. The work proposed will link these advances in paleomagnetism with those in studies of the geodynamo to produce more realistic dynamo models and understand how they are linked to deep Earth processes including dynamics of its fluid outer core and core-mantle interactions. Results from our research will contribute to inter-disciplinary studies of the deep Earth and will be broadly disseminated to others through publications in peer-reviewed literature and via interactions with other deep-Earth researchers contributing to other NSF-funded initiatives, particularly the CIDER (Cooperative Institute for Deep Earth Research) and CIG (Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics). We make a habit of systematic electronic archiving of tools and products in the EarthRef Digital Archive community database. These will be of use to other researchers in geo/paleomagnetism, and the images, models, and animations that we also archive will be useful for general research and educational purposes at multiple levels, providing tools for public education about the geomagnetic field. This project will also enhance future STEM activities and research through mentoring and training of a graduate student at Scripps. Education and outreach efforts will result from the PI's interactions with Scripps' Birch Aquarium and the ongoing NSF GK-12 program at Scripps.

Our assessment of millennial geomagnetic models suggests that they are adequate to study large-scale geomagnetic field variations in many regions of the world. On thousand year time-scales we observe mobility of the main concentrations of magnetic flux on the core-mantle boundary, generally low flux over the poles, and drift of features at lower latitudes. On million year time-scales we can map the average field and its statistical variability and we have time-varying models of the dipole moment, including its dramatic fall during polarity excursions and reversals. Parallel progress in dynamo simulation allows routine production of predominantly dipolar fields that are capable of self-reversal and, with appropriate boundary conditions, can mimic spatial structures observed over recent centuries and provide encouraging correlations over longer time-scales. The intent of this proposal is to tune such models so that they do a better job of reproducing inferred properties of paleofield variations, thereby enhancing our understanding of core dynamics. This will be accomplished by using a suite of simulations with accessible values of the Ekman, Rayleigh, and Prandtl numbers and engaging in a systematic exploration of changes in both vertical and lateral buoyancy profiles in the outer core that are linked to models of the thermal evolution of the core. This regime will allow investigation of the influence of strongly stably stratified layers at the top of the liquid core on the observable magnetic fields, and will provide insight about the thermal and chemical processes that lend structure and stability to the geomagnetic field. The magnetic field is one of the few direct observables that carry information about the deep Earth: we therefore expect our results to influence mineralogical and seismological models of deep Earth structure and core-mantle interaction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The geomagnetic field produced by a dynamo in the liquid outer core is an essential part of Earth’s immediate environment, serves as our primary shield against the solar wind and extreme space weather, and provides access to a record of Earth’s evolutionary history through paleomagnetic measurements.  The paleomagnetic record is fragmentary, noisy, and acquired at Earth’s surface almost 3000 km above the core surface. In contrast computational dynamo simulations allow detailed viewing of the interior magnetic field, temperature, and dynamics within the fluid shell used to mimic the outer core. However, computational limitations enforce a parameter regime lying far from that relevant to the Earth. Simulations cannot yet run with Earth-like diffusivities or rotation rates.

NSF funding was awarded to compare geodynamo simulations with models of the paleomagnetic field based on observations made over the last 2 million years. Simulations need tuning so that they do a better job of reproducing inferred properties of paleofield variations, thereby enhancing our understanding of core dynamics. At the same time work has continued on assessing paleomagnetic field variations to provide a better definition of what makes a numerical geodynamo simulation Earth-like.

PADM2M is a 2 million year long reconstruction of axial dipole moment (ADM) variations based on globally distributed relative and absolute paleointensity data and provides useful information about the spectrum of dipole moment variations. Notably it reveals large fluctuations in ADM (especially associated with occasional excursions and reversals) and an asymmetry in growth and decay rates of Earth’s dipole strength on timescales ranging between 25 and 100 kyr. The slower decay than growth suggests dominance of diffusive processes when the field is diminishing. Part of our work developed refined detection methods for this asymmetry. These were then used to identify evidence for similar asymmetry in the marine magnetic anomaly record (a different medium that also preserves a record of geomagnetic field variations) over both the same and different time intervals. This confirms the earlier paleomagnetic results, extends it to a new geological time interval ( 9.3-11.2 Ma), and supports the idea that this asymmetry can be used as an additional diagnostic for Earth-like field variations.

Dynamo simulations have been conducted with accessible values of key parameters (namely the Ekman (E), Rayleigh (Ra), and Prandtl numbers), and engaging in a systematic exploration of changes in both vertical and lateral buoyancy profiles in the outer core that are linked to models of the thermal evolution of the core.  We studied a broad range of simulations and found several that met previously proposed criteria for Earth-like properties. We have also been able to confirm that a few of these numerical simulations exhibit analogous asymmetry to PADM2M in rates of change of the dipole. Further study has allowed us to identify that the asymmetry in the numerical models is associated with greater Ohmic heating than work done by the Lorentz force.

However, more simulations show asymmetry between growth and decay in either the opposite sense to PADM2M or no significant asymmetry. In simulations differing from PADM2M, where field decays rapidly and grows slowly, the asymmetry is also reflected in the balance of Ohmic diffusion and work done by the Lorentz force, but the latter is more powerful. It seems that these are not viable candidates for Earth-like behavior. 

Many current simulations give good results for the static field but not for its time variations, and this has hampered the study of geomagnetic excursions and reversals. A systematic exploration of the easily accessible parameter regime has enabled identification of strong and weak field branches of dynamo simulations, opening a promising avenue for further exploration, through variations of the magnetic Prandtl number which reflects the ratio of viscous to magnetic diffusivity. This may allow the large scale variations in axial dipole moment in dipole-dominated dynamos that seem necessary to produce Earth-like geomagnetic excursions and reversals.

This project has promoted fruitful collaborations with faculty and postdoctoral scholars at Leeds university, UK, led to further development of the Leeds Boussinesq dynamo code, and enhanced visualization of the results, and facilitated developing new numerical and technical skills for geomagnetists at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. A PhD student has been involved with all stages of this project, thereby contributing to STEM workforce development.   In addition to scientific conference and workshop presentations, contributions to outreach include the PhD student’s development of a module on geomagnetism for the UCSD Splash program for high school students, and lectures by the PI at UCSD’s COSMOS and SURF summer programs for high school and undergraduate students.
